questions.text:
A 52-year-old female presents with a two-month history of persistent itching, redness, and scaling of the right nipple, unresponsive to moisturizing creams. Physical examination reveals erythema and crusting of the nipple and areola without palpable breast lumps. The image of her right breast is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paget disease of the nipple

Explanation:

The given case scenario is that of Paget’s disease of the nipple

Finding

Description

Possible Cause

Nipple discharge

Discharge from a single duct orifice

Papilloma (Option C) or other underlying ductal disease

Paget disease of the nipple

Appears as a psoriatic rash starting on the nipple and spreading to the areola and breast skin.

Paget disease

Skin dimpling
  • Traction on Cooper ligaments by a scirrhous tumor
  • Best seen with angled indirect lighting during the abduction of the arms upward.

Scirrhous tumor (Option B)

Peau d’orange (skin of the orange)

Edema of the breast skin
  • Inflammatory carcinoma (Option D)
  • Lymphatic blockage
  • Mastitis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer opts for surgery that involves the removal of the entire breast, including the nipple and areola, but not the axillary lymph nodes. Which type of mastectomy is she likely undergoing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Total (Simple) Mastectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Mastectomy: Surgical procedure to remove one or both breasts, typically to treat or prevent breast cancer.

Types of Mastectomy

Types

Structures removed

Simple/Total mastectomy (Option A)

En bloc removal of

  • Nipple
  • Areola
  • Breast mass
  • Skin

Extended mastectomy (Total Mastectomy with Axillary Dissection) (Option D)

Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes

Halsted/Radical mastectomy (Option C)

Simple mastectomy + removal of level I, II, III axillary lymph nodes + excision of pectoralis major and minor muscle.

Modified Radical Mastectomy(MRM) (Option B)

Simple mastectomy + removal of level I, II axillary lymph nodes

 

Variants :

  • Auchincloss modification : MRM
  • Patey’s modification: MRM + excision of pectoralis minor
  • Scanlons modification: MRM + division of pectoralis minor(removal and resuturing)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication for breast-conserving surgery (BCS)?

choices.text: Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage IIB breast cancer

Explanation:

Breast-conserving surgery (BCS), also known as lumpectomy, involves removing a breast tumor along with a small margin of surrounding healthy tissue while preserving the majority of the breast.

  • The goal is to remove the cancerous cells while maintaining the breast's appearance and function.
  • Performed for early invasive breast cancer (Stage I, IIA, IIB)

 

Absolute Contraindications for breast-conserving surgery (BCS):

 

Absolute Contraindications
  • Pregnancy (Option D ruled out) because after BCS postop radiotherapy will be necessary which is not possible in case pregnancy.
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse malignant microcalcifications on mammogram suggests widespread disease, making complete excision with clear margins unlikely (Option B ruled out)
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast  cannot give radiation again, which is essential after BCS(Option A ruled out)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of the Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) for DCIS?


	Tumor size
	Margin status
	Histological grade
	Patient age
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3 & 4

Explanation:

"Micro Swag" Mnemonic for the components of VPNI
Micro- Microcalcification
S-Size
W-Width of margin
A-Age
G-Grade

Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) for Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS)
 

Factor

Score 1

Score 2

Score 3

Tumor Size

≤ 15 mm

16-40 mm

>40 mm

Margin Status

>10 mm

1-9 mm

<1 mm

Histological Grade
  • Grade I/II
  • Well-differentiated
  • Necrosis absent
  • Grade I/II
  • Moderately differentiated
  • Necrosis present
  • Grade III
  • Poorly differentiated
  • Necrosis present

Patient Age

> 61 years

40-60 years

< 39 years

 

VNPI Score Calculation

The VNPI score is the sum of points from all four factors. The total score is used to stratify the risk and guide treatment decisions

  • Total Score 4-6: Low risk
  • Total Score 7-9: Intermediate risk
  • Total Score 10-12: High risk

questions.text: Which of the following describes the basal type of breast malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ER-, PR-, and HER2 neu-

Explanation:

 

Molecular classification of breast cancer

 

Subtype

ER Status

PR Status

HER2 Status

Ki-67 Status

Characteristics

Luminal A

+

+

-

Low

Generally low grade, better prognosis, responsive to hormonal therapy.

Luminal B

+

+ or -

+ or -

High

Higher grade, poor prognosis compared to Luminal A, may require targeted HER2 therapy following status.

HER2-enriched

-

-

+

High

Aggressive, higher grade, poor prognosis, requires targeted HER2 therapy.

Basal-like

-

-

-

High

Includes triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), highly aggressive, no targeted hormonal therapy.

Claudin-low

-

-

+ or -

Often High

Often associated with poor prognosis and aggressive behavior, typically lacks response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast lump. After imaging studies and a biopsy, the results show a tumor measuring 3.5 cm in the breast. The patient also has involvement of ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes, but no distant metastases are detected. Based on the TNM staging system, what is the appropriate stage for this breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T2 N2

 

Explanation:

(T2 N2) The tumor size of 3.5 cm fits the T2 category (tumor > 2.0 cm but ≤ 5.0 cm).

  • The involvement of ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes is classified as N2, and no distant metastases (M0) are present.

TNM staging for breast cancer

Stage

Description

Tumor size (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (DCIS, LCIS, or Paget's disease)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm

T1mi

Tumor ≤ 1 mm

T1a

Tumor > 1 mm but ≤ 5 mm

T1b

Tumor > 5 mm but ≤ 10 mm

T1c

Tumor > 10 mm but ≤ 20 mm

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 5 cm

T3

Tumor > 5 cm

T4

Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

T4a

Extension to chest wall

T4b

Ulceration or skin nodules

T4c

Both T4a and T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to movable ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or clinically apparent internal mammary nodes

N2a

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted

N2b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes without axillary lymph node involvement

N3

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or infraclavicular nodes, or to supraclavicular nodes

N3a

Metastasis to infraclavicular nodes

N3b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes

N3c

Metastasis to supraclavicular nodes

Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

 

Stage Grouping

Stage 0: Tis N0 M0

Stage IA: T1/T1mi N0 M0

Stage IB: T0 N1mi M0; T1/T1mi N1mi M0

Stage IIA: T0 N1 M0; T1 N1 M0; T2 N0 M0

Stage IIB: T2 N1 M0; T3 N0 M0

Stage IIIA: T0 N2 M0; T1 N2 M0; T2 N2 M0; T3 N1 M0

Stage IIIB: T3 N2 M0

Stage IIIC: T4 N0 M0; T4 N1 M0; T4 N2 M0; Any T N3 M0

Stage IV: Any T Any N M1

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents for her routine mammogram. She has no family history of breast cancer and no previous history of breast issues. A mammogram reveals a well-circumscribed, homogeneous lesion with characteristic benign features, such as a simple cyst with no suspicious calcifications or architectural distortions. Based on these findings, What is the appropriate BI-RADS category for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) BI-RADS 2

Explanation:

The scenario describes a well-circumscribed, homogeneous lesion with characteristic benign features, such as a simple cyst with no suspicious calcifications or architectural distortions.

  • This suggests lesion is Benign and so BIRADS 2 is the appropriate score for this situation.

BI-RADS Score:

BI-RADS Category

Description

Management

Likelihood of Malignancy

0

Incomplete

Need additional imaging evaluation

N/A

1

Negative

Routine screening

Essentially 0%

2

Benign

Routine screening

Essentially 0%

3

Probably Benign

Short-term follow-up (6 months)

< 2%

4

Suspicious of Malignancy

Biopsy should be considered

  

4A

Suspicious: Low

_

> 2% to ≤ 10%

4B

Suspicious: Moderate

_

> 10% to ≤ 50%

4C

Suspicious: High

_

> 50% to ≤ 95%

5

Highly Suggestive of Malignancy

Appropriate action should be taken

> 95%

6

Known Biopsy-Proven Malignancy

Appropriate action should be taken

100%

questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			Biopsy
			
			
			Feature
			
		
		
			
			1. FNAC
			
			
			a. Evaluation of cellular fibroadenoma
			
		
		
			
			2. Core-needle biopsy
			
			
			b. Assessment of suspicious lymph nodes
			
		
		
			
			3. Excisional biopsy
			
			
			c. Sampling solid masses, calcifications, and densities identified on imaging
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b,2-c,3-a

 

Explanation:

 

Biopsy Type

Indications

Fine-needle aspiration Cytology (FNAC)
  • Assessment of suspicious lymph nodes

Core Needle Biopsy (CNB)
  • Sampling solid masses, calcifications, and densities identified on imaging

Excisional Biopsy
  • Evaluation of atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) or cellular fibroadenoma

questions.text: A 48-year-old female underwent a lumpectomy for a 2 cm invasive ductal carcinoma in her right breast. Post-surgery pathology revealed positive margins, indicating residual cancerous tissue. Which of the following investigations is most suitable to check for residual cancer tissues?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI

Explanation:

MRI is preferred for checking for residual disease after lumpectomy with positive margins.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in breast cancer

Indications:

  • Tumors in patients with axillary lymph node metastases and no mammographic evidence
  • Paget disease of the nipple without radiographic evidence of a primary tumor
  • The extent of the primary tumor, especially in young women with dense breast tissue
  • Residual disease after lumpectomy with positive margins
  • Screening the contralateral breast
  • Invasive lobular cancers
  • After neoadjuvant chemotherapy
  • Assessing implant rupture or evaluating the breast after silicone injection.

questions.text: A lesion was found in a routine mammogram of a 52-year-old asymptomatic woman. Which of the following statements regarding mammogram findings is false?

choices.text: If the density of the lesion is high, it is mostly malignant
Architectural distortion is usually present in benign lesions
Calcification in benign lesions is diffuse
Margins are well-circumscribed in benign lesions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Architectural distortion is usually present in benign lesions

 

Explanation:

 

Architectural distortion is usually present in malignant lesions, not benign lesions

Mammography findings

 

Feature

Benign Lesions

Malignant Lesions

Shape

Round, oval, lobular

Irregular

Margins

Circumscribed

Microlobulated, obscured, indistinct, spiculated

Density

Low to intermediate

Intermediate to high

Distribution of Calcifications

Randomly distributed, diffuse

Grouped, clustered, fine linear, branching, segmental

Architectural Distortion

Usually absent

Often present

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless lump in her right breast, noticed during a self-examination two weeks ago. Which of the following tests has the maximum accuracy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Triple assessment

 

Explanation:

Triple assessment is a combination of assessments used for breast cancer screening and diagnosis

Triple Assessment of Breast Examination

1. Clinical Examination

Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy.

Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes.

2. Imaging

Methods:

  • Mammography: Preferred for women over 40.
  • Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation.

3. Biopsy

Types:

  • FNAC: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions.
  • Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses.
  • Excisional: Removes lump for examination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lymphatic drainage of the breast is true?

choices.text: Level III lymph nodes are located lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle.
Lymphatic drainage from the breast is directed to the subclavian lymph nodes.
Level I lymph nodes are also known as rotter’s nodes.
Level II lymph nodes are located posterior to the pectoralis major

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Level II lymph nodes are located posterior to the pectoralis major

Explanation:

Axillary lymph nodes are categorised into three anatomical levels based on their relationship to the pectoralis minor muscle.

Level of node

Location

Level I

Lateral and below to the lateral border of pectoralis minor

Level II(Rotter/Interpectoral nodes)

Anterior as well as posterior to the pectoralis minor and posterior to the pectoralis major.

Level III

Medial and above to the pectoralis minor muscle and include subclavicular nodes

questions.text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of frequency of metastasis in breast cancer

choices.text: Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull
Lumbar vertebrae> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull> femur
Thoracic vertebrae>lumbar vertebrae> ribs> skull> femur
Thoracic vertebrae> femur> lumbar vertebrae> ribs> skull

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull

Explanation:

LFT RISK- mnemonic
Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull

Spread of breast cancer

Local Invasion
  • Tumors invade nearby tissues (skin, chest wall).

Lymphatic Spread
  • Cancer cells spread to nearby lymph nodes

Hematogenous Spread
  • Cancer cells enter the bloodstream indicating stage IV cancer.
  • Metastasising to distant organs in frequency :
    • Bones> lungs> liver> brain
  • Among bones frequency:
    • Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull (Option A)

Multifocal Growth
  • Cancers may appear as multiple independent foci within the same breast or different quadrants
  • Common in invasive lobular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. The pathology report shows a 2.5 cm tumor with positive lymph nodes. The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her prognosis and treatment?

choices.text: The tumor size and lymph node status suggest a favorable prognosis
The hormone receptor status indicates the tumor will not respond to endocrine therapy
The absence of HER2 overexpression means targeted therapies are the primary treatment option
The ER-positive status suggests a better prognosis and responsiveness to endocrine therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The ER-positive status suggests a better prognosis and responsiveness to endocrine therapy

 

Explanation:

Disease factors that influence prognosis

Tumour Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumour size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumours and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis. (Option A)

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR): ER-positive = better prognosis (Option D), responsive to endocrine therapy. (Option B)
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies. (Option C)

questions.text: A 38-year-old premenopausal woman is diagnosed with Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) after a breast biopsy. She opts for chemoprevention as her management strategy. Her doctor discusses various medication options with her. Which of the following statements about chemoprevention for LCIS is correct?

choices.text: Chemoprevention eliminates the risk of developing breast cancer
Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 25% over 5 years
Chemoprevention is only effective for the ipsilateral breast
Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years.

 

Explanation:

Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS)

Management

  • Close observation
  • Chemoprevention
    • Medications: Tamoxifen, Raloxifene, or Arimidex
    • Tamoxifen reduces risk by 56% over 5 years
  • Surgical: Bilateral mastectomy (if surgery chosen prophylactically)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman undergoes a routine mammogram, which reveals clustered calcifications in her left breast. Further investigation confirms the diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The lesion is small, low-grade, and has clear margins. The patient expresses a strong desire to preserve her breast if possible. What is the most appropriate initial treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lumpectomy alone.

Explanation:

 

Given that the DCIS is small, low-grade, and has clear margins, the scenario describes a low-risk case.

  • Considering the patient's desire for breast preservation, breast-conserving surgery (Lumpectomy) alone is appropriate.

 

Ductal Carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

Treatment

  • Mastectomy
    • Near-certain cure rate (98-99% survival)
    • 1-2% lifetime risk of local recurrence
  • Breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) with radiation
    • Reduces recurrence risk compared to lumpectomy alone (Option B)
  • Breast-conserving surgery alone
    • For specific low-risk cases (Option C)

Adjuvant Therapies

 

  • Hormonal therapy (e.g., Tamoxifen) (Option A)
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB)
    • Recommended for mastectomy patients
    • Considered in specific breast-conserving surgery cases

questions.text: All of the following are invasive carcinomas except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fibroadenoma

Explanation

Classification of breast cancer

 

Invasive Carcinomas
  • Invasive Carcinoma of No Special Type (NST)
  • Special Subtypes of Invasive Carcinoma:
    • Invasive Ductal carcinoma (Option A)
    • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma: Classic, solid, alveolar, pleomorphic, and tubulolobular variants. (Option B)
    • Tubular Carcinoma
    • Cribriform Carcinoma
    • Mucinous Carcinoma: Characterized by mucin production, good prognosis.
    • Medullary Carcinoma: Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, associated with BRCA1 mutations. (Option C)
    • Metaplastic Carcinoma
    • Invasive Micropapillary Carcinoma
    • Carcinomas with Apocrine Differentiation

Benign Epithelial Proliferations
  • Fibroadenomas (Option D)
  • Phyllodes Tumors

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common model used for breast cancer risk assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gail Model

Explanation:

 

Risk assessment models of breast carcinoma

Two main models are used

  • Gail model
  • Clause model

 

Gail model

Clause model

Most commonly used (Option A)

More information about family history

Absolute risk estimation

Relative risk estimation

It is assessed with

  • Age at menarche
  • Number of 1st°relatives with breast carcinoma
  • Age at first life birth
  • Number of breast biopsies

It is assessed with

  • 1st° and 2nd° relatives with breast cancer
  • Age of diagnosis of relatives

Framingham Risk Score (Option B): Primarily used for assessing the risk of cardiovascular disease, not breast cancer.

 

ASCVD Risk Estimator (Option C): Used to assess the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, not breast cancer.

 

QRISK3 (Option D): Model used to predict the risk of cardiovascular disease, not breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about breast cancer risk factors is true?

choices.text: The median age of breast cancer presentation is 60 years in India
The relative risk of Papillomatosis is 8-10
Relative Risk for breast cancer in 1st-degree relative is 3
Early onset of menstruation increases breast cancer risk.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Early onset of menstruation increases breast cancer risk.

Explanation:

 

Risk factors for breast cancer

 

Non-modifiable risk factors

Age

  • Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK,USA) While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India.(Option A)

Family history of breast cancer

  • 1 first degree relative RR= 2(option C)

Early Menarche(<12years)

Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19 (Option D)

High-risk breast lesions

  • Complex fibroadenoma RR=3
  • Papillomatosis RR=3(Option B)
  • Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intraductal papilloma

Explanation:

Nipple Discharge

Type of Nipple Discharge

Causes

Bloody
  • Intraductal Papilloma (Most Common)
  • Breast Carcinoma
  • Duct Ectasia

Serous

  • Fibrocystic Disease (Most Common)
  • Breast Carcinoma
  • Duct Ectasia

Greenish/Blackish
  • Duct Ectasia

Milk (Galactorrhea)
  • Physiological (e.g., Pregnancy, Lactation)
  • Hyperprolactinemia (e.g., Pituitary Adenoma, Hypothyroidism)
  • Medications (e.g., Antipsychotics, Antidepressants, Oral Contraceptives)

Purulent
  • Breast Abscess
  • Mastitis

questions.text: What is the primary arterial supply to the superior part of the breast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thoracoacromial artery

Explanation:

 

Artery

Areas Supplied

Internal thoracic artery (Option A)

Medial and central parts of the breast

Lateral thoracic artery (Option B)

Lateral aspect of the breast

Thoracoacromial artery (Option C)

Superior part of the breast

Posterior intercostal arteries (Option D)

Lateral and posterior aspects of the breast

Superior thoracic artery

Upper part of the breast (limited supply)

Subscapular artery

Lower part of the breast
